DbMaintenance package¶

Module contents¶

class wrapper_classes.DbMaintenance.DbMaintenance[source]¶

Database Maintenance wrapper class that is designed to abstract away Database specifics in order to avoid major refactoring when the backing database changes.

close_connection()[source]¶

A method to close a connection to the database if it exists.

commit()[source]¶

A method to commit the transaction to the database.

Return Bool:True if the commit is successful, else False.
execute_procedure(procedure, args, log_file)[source]¶

A method to execute a stored procedure that manages the database connection and returns a list of results.

Parameters:
  • procedure – A string that names the stored procedure to be executed.
  • args – A list or other mutable sequence containing the parameters required to execute procedure. Arg types must match the types of the input vars in procedure. See stored procedure documentation.
  • log_file – The path to the log file to be written to.
Return list:

A list of tuples with the results.
Return []:

If there are no results or the call failed for any reason.
execute_statement(statement=None, values=None, commit=False)[source]¶

A method to execute statement with vales passed as args. The transaction is committed only if commit is True. Otherwise the commit method must be called.

Parameters:
  • statement – A valid static or prepared MySql expression.
  • values – A tuple, a list of tuples, or None. If not None, then values is passed to the database with the statement.
  • commit – A flag that controls whether or not the transaction is committed.
Return Bool:

True if the statement is successfully executed in the database. Otherwise, False.
get_cursor(stored=False)[source]¶
Parameters:stored – A bool that determines if the cursor supports prepared statements or not. Only set to false if you are calling a stored procedure. Prepared statements help protect against sql injections.
Return Bool:True if a cursor is created, else False.
get_results(stored=False)[source]¶

A method to convert the tuples returned by the database into a list of tuples.

Parameters:stored – A bool with default value False. Set to True only if this call is being made directly after calling a stored procedure. However, if you use the provided methods, you shouldn’t need to ever set this to True.
Return list:A list of tuples returned by the database.
Return []:If no tuples are returned or if an error occurred.
import_db_config(config_file)[source]¶

Sets the database endpoint information with the data in config_file. Successfully importing the endpoint information does not guarantee that a connection to the database can be made.

Parameters:config_file – A yaml file with the following format:

..testcode:

db:
  ip: localhost
  username: username
  password: password
  database: database
Return Bool:True if the data is successfully imported, else False.
open_connection()[source]¶

A method to open a connection to the backing database.

Return Bool:True if a connection is established, else False.
populate_db(statement, log_file, values)[source]¶

A wrapper function that prepares statement and then executes statement with the provided values. :param statement: A string with a valid MySQL expression in prepared statement form. :param log_file: The path to the log file to be written to. :param values: A tuple or a list of tuples with the values to be inserted into the database. :return Bool: True if the values are successfully inserted into the database, else False.

prepare_statement(statement)[source]¶

A method to prepare a statement in the database. This method should be called prior to to calling execute_statement if args are to be passed to with the statement to the db.

Parameters:statement – A valid MySql prepared statement.
Return Bool:If statement successfully prepares the statement, else False.
pull_from_db(statement, log_file, values_list=None)[source]¶

A wrapper function to pull data from the database. It accepts either a static MySQL expression or a’prapared statement.

Select * from Players; # static statement
Select * from Players where playerId = %s; # prepared statement that requires a value_list
Parameters:
  • statement – A valid MySQL statement that is either a static expression or if values_list is not None a valid prepared statement.
  • log_file – The path the the log file to be written to.
  • values_list – A tuple to be used as the arguments for the prepared statement generated from statement.
Return list:

A list of tuples with the values returned from the database
Return []:

If the database returns a empty result set or the statement can not be executed.
set_db_config(username, password, ip, database)[source]¶

A method to update the database endpoint variables.

Parameters:
  • username – Database username
  • password – Database password
  • ip – the ip address or host name of the database
  • database – The name of a database schema to use.
